security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate Git branching management skill with appropriate permissions. It uses subprocess to run git commands for branch operations, reads/writes configuration files in project-specific locations, and has no network access or persistence mechanisms. All code execution is controlled via hardcoded git command arrays.

content.user_title: Manage Git branches with automated workflows
content.value_statement: Managing Git branches manually leads to inconsistent naming, merge conflicts, and release chaos. This skill provides flow-aware automation for branch creation, validation, and cleanup across Gitflow, GitHub Flow, trunk-based, and GitLab Flow strategies.
actual_capabilities: Create and validate branches following Gitflow, GitHub Flow, trunk-based, or GitLab Flow strategies
Generate branch names with proper prefixes, issue references, and naming conventions
Automate gitflow operations including feature start/finish, release preparation, and hotfix workflows
Manage git worktrees for parallel development without stashing
Validate branch names, flow compliance, and merge targets against configured rules
Clean up merged branches and worktrees with safety checks
limitations: Requires Git 2.17+ for full worktree support
Configuration file must exist at .claude/github-workflows/branching-config.json for advanced features
Cannot modify remote repository branch protection rules directly
Does not handle merge conflicts automatically - requires manual resolution

use_cases.title: Standardize team branching
use_cases.description: Enforce consistent branch naming, prefixes, and merge workflows across the entire team with automated validation.

use_cases.title: Automate release workflows
use_cases.description: Streamline release branch creation, version bumping, changelog generation, and multi-branch merging.

use_cases.title: Parallel feature development
use_cases.description: Use git worktrees to work on multiple branches simultaneously without losing context or stashing changes.

prompt_templates.title: Create feature branch
prompt_templates.prompt: Start a feature branch for [feature description] based on issue #[issue number]

prompt_templates.title: Finish feature
prompt_templates.prompt: Finish the current feature branch and merge it following gitflow conventions

prompt_templates.title: Emergency hotfix
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a hotfix branch from main for [bug description] with isolated worktree

prompt_templates.title: Validate branch policy
prompt_templates.prompt: Validate all branches in this repository follow our naming conventions and flow rules

output_examples.input: Start a feature branch for user authentication based on issue 42
output: Next: Make changes, commit with 'feat(auth): description', then run /branch-finish when done

best_practices: Initialize the branching configuration before first use to define your strategy and naming rules
Use worktrees for parallel development to avoid context switching and stashing
Validate branch names before creation to catch naming violations early
Clean up merged branches regularly to keep the repository organized
anti_patterns: Creating branches directly on main without going through the configured flow
Using underscores or uppercase letters in branch names (breaks convention)
Keeping feature branches alive longer than necessary (causes merge conflicts)
Merging to the wrong target branch (feature to main instead of develop)

faq.question: Which branching strategies are supported?
faq.answer: Gitflow, GitHub Flow, GitLab Flow, trunk-based development, and simple flow templates are included.

faq.question: How long can feature branches live?
faq.answer: For gitflow: 1-2 weeks max. For trunk-based: less than 2 days. Shorter branches reduce merge conflicts.

faq.question: Does this integrate with GitHub?
faq.answer: It works with local git operations. GitHub integration requires additional GitHub CLI or API skills.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: All operations run locally. Configuration is stored in your project directory. No external network calls are made.

faq.question: Why are my branches failing validation?
faq.answer: Check branch naming rules in your config. Common issues: uppercase letters, underscores, missing prefixes, or wrong base branch.
